meanings.def: a large boat that carries people or goods by sea
examples: The yard builds ships for the Navy.
on a ship The others sailed on a later ship.
aboard a ship The goods had been loaded aboard a ship destined for Montreal.
There are two restaurants on board ship.
a cargo/cruise/merchant ship
a Navy ship
a ship’s company (= the crew of a ship)
a ship’s captain/crew/officers
by ship Raw materials and labour come by ship, rail or road.
The captain gave the order to abandon ship (= to leave the ship because it was sinking).
a fleet of ships
They boarded a ship bound for India.
When the ship docked at Southampton he was rushed to hospital.
The dockers were loading the cargo onto the ship.
Their ship lay at anchor in the bay.
The ship is now permanently moored in Buenos Aires.
a ship carrying more than a thousand people
a container ship
The captain went down with his ship.
The crew was rescued by a passing ship.

meanings.def: used to talk about people who leave an organization, a company, etc. that is having difficulties, without caring about the people who are left
to leave the ship on which you are serving, without permission
to leave an organization that you belong to, suddenly and unexpectedly
to organize something in a very efficient way, controlling other people very closely
to cause something good to fail because you did not spend a small but necessary amount of money or time on a small but essential part of it

idioms.def: used to talk about people who leave an organization, a company, etc. that is having difficulties, without caring about the people who are left
to leave the ship on which you are serving, without permission
to organize something in a very efficient way, controlling other people very closely

idioms.idiom: spoil the ship for a ha’p’orth/ha’pennyworth of tar

examples: ownership
friendship
citizenship
professorship
musicianship
membership

meanings.def: to send or transport somebody/something by ship or by another means of transport
examples: The company ships its goods all over the world.
He was arrested and shipped back to the UK for trial.
Within four years they were shipping fabrics to customers in Australia.
The vehicles are shipped by rail and truck.
How much would it cost to ship this to Japan?
They are due to ship a cargo of nuclear waste from France.
Thousands of orphans were shipped abroad in the 1960s and 1970s.

meanings.def: to be available to be bought; to make something available to be bought
examples: The software is due to ship next month.
ship something The company continues to ship more computer systems than its rivals.

meanings.def: to have water coming in over the sides
to think that two people should be in a romantic relationship
examples: Some people are already shipping Alex and Meredith.
People ship Emma with Jack because he’s so hot and funny!

meanings.def: used to tell somebody that if they do not improve, work harder, etc. they will have to leave their job, position, etc.
examples: He finally faced up to his drug problem when his band told him to shape up or ship out.

idioms.def: used to tell somebody that if they do not improve, work harder, etc. they will have to leave their job, position, etc.
examples: He finally faced up to his drug problem when his band told him to shape up or ship out.
